snippet: The Seahawks and Vikings may rack up points and the Colts and Browns will square off in a battle of second-tier contenders. That is, if the N.F.L. plays through coronavirus setbacks. More positive tests for the coronavirus. A hurricane possibly forcing a game to be moved. A top matchup delayed indefinitely. Several prominent players out with major injuries. The news has not been good over the last few weeks for the N.F.L., and while the on-field product has remained strong, the growing list of issues is certainly a concern.

headline: N.F.L.’s Coronavirus Cases Rise With New Positive Tests
snippet: Patriots cornerback Stephon Gilmore was among the confirmed cases in this week’s testing. Two more Titans tested positive, throwing Sunday’s game against Buffalo into doubt. For the second straight week, the N.F.L. is grappling with the fallout from positive coronavirus tests, an existential threat to the league’s adherence to playing the season according to its schedule.

headline: LeBron James Is Mr. October This Year
snippet: The Los Angeles Lakers superstar has his team on the brink of a championship at an unusual time, in an unusual year. The former Yankees star Reggie Jackson is watching. Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.

headline: Round 4 of the Cage Match Goes to … the Lakers
snippet: The physical toll of the N.B.A. finals was on display before, during and after Los Angeles’s victory LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Anthony Davis of the Los Angeles Lakers caught fingers in his eye and elbows in his chest, and that was before his teammate Alex Caruso banged into his legs, both players tumbling like bowling pins. LeBron James made a layup after a fender-bender of his own, then flexed his biceps while flat on his back.

headline: The Yankees Tried a Sneaky Move With All the Wrong Pieces
snippet: Manager Aaron Boone tried to take a page out of the Rays’ playbook to beat Tampa Bay, but it backfired without crucial buy-in from his pitcher. The Yankees tried to beat the Tampa Bay Rays at their own game in their American League division series on Tuesday. But they failed to grasp how that game is played.

headline: Russell Wilson Leads the N.F.L. M.V.P. Race, but Josh Allen Is …
snippet: Smart money is on the Seattle quarterback receiving at least a vote or two this year. But the better bet, counter-intuitively, might be the Bills’ Josh Allen. Russell Wilson may lead the N.F.L. in touchdowns and Dak Prescott in passing yards, but Josh Allen leads the league by a wide margin in cognitive dissonance.

headline: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Wednesday
snippet: Novak Djokovic and Sofia Kenin, the Australian Open champions, look to advance to the French Open semifinals against familiar opposition. How to watch: 6 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on the Tennis Channel; streaming on the Tennis Channel app.

headline: Rays Jump on Yankees’ Pitching Trickery to Even Series
snippet: Giancarlo Stanton hit two home runs, but Tampa Bay hit homers off Deivi Garcia and J.A. Happ to tie the American League division series at one game apiece. SAN DIEGO — The Yankees surprised many when they tabbed Deivi Garcia, a 21-year-old rookie pitcher, to start Game 2 of their American League division series on Tuesday at Petco Park — including Garcia himself. And while Manager Aaron Boone was understandably coy before the game when asked how long he planned to use the largely unproven Garcia, the answer arrived only moments into the young pitcher’s start.

headline: Travis d’Arnaud, Long an October Footnote, Gets His Moment
snippet: The 31-year-old Braves catcher has had a career hindered by injuries, but he delivered a momentum-swinging home run in Game 1 against the Marlins. It was a decade ago Tuesday, in a different National League division series opener, that the October value of Travis d’Arnaud started to reveal itself.

headline: Jill Ellis Wants More Women on the Sideline
snippet: A new initiative by U.S. Soccer and the former women’s national team coach will try to address the gender gap in top-flight coaching. Yes, Jill Ellis thinks about coaching again. Yes, the former United States women’s soccer coach said, she has had offers. Yes, she would take the right one if it came along.

headline: Rafael Nadal, After a Late Night at the French Open, Will Face Diego Schwartzman in the Semifinals
snippet: Schwartzman outlasted Dominic Thiem in a match that took more than five hours, while Nadal defeated Jannik Sinner in straight sets. Diego Schwartzman had to play for more than five hours to defeat the third-seeded Dominic Thiem in five sets at Roland Garros, while Rafael Nadal required just three sets to beat Jannik Sinner, an unseeded 19-year-old Italian.

headline: Seattle Storm Win the W.N.B.A. Championship
snippet: The Storm beat the top-seeded Las Vegas Aces behind Breanna Stewart, Sue Bird, Jewell Loyd and a talented roster of veterans. Breanna Stewart and Sue Bird sat side by side on the Seattle Storm’s bench, wide smiles across their faces as they chatted.

headline: Yankees and Astros Look Formidable in the A.L. Playoffs
snippet: Two strong teams took 1-0 leads, and a third New York-Houston series seems likely. Let’s put the caveat up front: Nobody clinches a best-of-five series in Game 1. The Tampa Bay Rays and the Oakland Athletics won their divisions emphatically this season, and both could come back to meet in the American League Championship Series.

headline: Monday Night Is Missing Its Mojo
snippet: Green Bay (4-0) beat Atlanta in an empty Lambeau Field, one of two games Monday night in an N.F.L. that keeps plowing headlong into the pandemic. GREEN BAY, Wis. — The hospitals here are nearing capacity with coronavirus patients. The Bishop of the Catholic Diocese has told his flock that they can stay home and did not have to attend Sunday Mass. Gov. Tony Evers was even more direct about the grip the pandemic has on his state.

headline: Bill O’Brien Wasn’t the Only Coach Presiding Over a Bad Start
snippet: Houston fired O’Brien, its head coach and general manager, on Monday after four straight losses. Three N.F.C. teams also have to turn their seasons around. There was once a home in Houston. It teemed with amenities, and on the outside it shimmered. But inside, termites gnawed at the floors, a sewage pipe neared bursting and structural issues diminished its value.

headline: The French Open Cold Drives Kenin and Djokovic Toward the Drop Shot
snippet: A well-disguised drop shot barely passes over the net and dies when it hits the red clay. Often, it has also been a winner in Paris. Sofia Kenin, who is having the most successful season of any American tennis player, is eager to deploy her drop shot on any surface.

headline: N.H.L. Draft: Rangers Select Alexis Lafreniere With First Overall Pick
snippet: Lafreniere, the consensus top prospect, had 112 points in 52 games last season in the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League. He will join a young Rangers core. The Rangers selected left wing Alexis Lafreniere, the consensus top prospect, with the No. 1 pick on Tuesday night in an N.H.L. draft conducted virtually because of the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Dusty Baker: The Beloved Manager Leading a Hated Team
snippet: Even those who despise the Houston Astros for their cheating scandal have trouble disparaging Baker, who has earned unrivaled good will over five decades in the majors. Soon after the Houston Astros completed a two-game sweep of the Minnesota Twins in their first-round playoff series last week, Dusty Baker’s phone went into overdrive: Scores of congratulatory texts, emails and calls came pouring in from friends, family and many others around baseball.

headline: Yankees Turn to a 21-Year-Old Rookie for His Unflappability
snippet: Deivi Garcia, who was picked over the veteran Masahiro Tanaka, will be the youngest starting pitcher in Yankees postseason history. SAN DIEGO — In an exhibition game just before the season began on July 23, the Yankees pitching prospect Deivi Garcia started a game against the Philadelphia Phillies. In the words of Manager Aaron Boone, Garcia didn’t look very good. He tossed 46 pitches to get five outs, coughing up seven base runners and two runs.

headline: LeBron James’s Teammates Beat Him, Then Joined Him
snippet: A handful of James’s Los Angeles Lakers teammates played for teams that knocked him out of past playoffs. No hard feelings? When he was on the verge of reaching the 2020 N.B.A. finals, LeBron James offered praise to some of his Los Angeles Lakers teammates who helped bring the team to championship contention.

headline: N.F.L. Adds New Covid-19 Protocols to Keep Season on Track
snippet: The league introduced new measures, including video surveillance to monitor the wearing of masks while in team facilities or traveling, after postponing games because of an outbreak. Working overtime to keep its season intact, N.F.L. officials on Monday afternoon introduced additions to existing coronavirus protocols established with the players’ union following a call between the league office, team owners, general managers and head coaches.

headline: 2020 French Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
snippet: Rafael Nadal and Elina Svitolina take on first-time major quarterfinalists as the French Open consolidates to the two main show courts. How to watch: 6 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on the Tennis Channel; streaming on the Tennis Channel app.

headline: Jannik Sinner’s First Sport Was Skiing. It’s Helped Him Play Fearlessly in Tennis.
snippet: Sinner, 19, has caught the attention of the tennis world with his quick ascent up the singles rankings. His next test is Rafael Nadal at the French Open. Before Jannik Sinner took his first steps toward scaling the world tennis ladder, he was quickly descending mountains in the Italian Alps.

headline: The Aces Got to the Top With Physical Play. What Happened?
snippet: Las Vegas could lose the W.N.B.A. finals to the Seattle Storm on Tuesday. A return to bruising defense and attacking drives may save its season. The Las Vegas Aces battled and bruised other teams en route to the top seed this W.N.B.A. season. A’ja Wilson dominated the block on both sides of the court, and Angel McCoughtry sliced through defenders with ease. Driving to the basket, getting to the foul line and pushing the pace were what made the Aces championship contenders.

headline: Beware of Diego Schwartzman, a Tennis David in a Sport of Goliaths
snippet: Schwartzman is among the shortest players in elite tennis, but at this unique French Open, he has become a brutal opponent. He beat Dominic Thiem in a quarterfinal on Tuesday. Modern men’s professional tennis does not really do small.

headline: The Eagles Are 1-2-1. And in First Place in the N.F.C. East.
snippet: Want to make the playoffs with a losing record? Maybe join the N.F.L.’s worst division. It’s been a while since the storied heyday of the N.F.C. East. From 1980 to 2000, teams currently in the division won the Super Bowl seven times. Overall, the N.F.C. East has produced 13 Super Bowl champions and made 21 appearances in the game.

headline: After 12 Years, a Yankees Scout’s Dream Pairing Comes to Fruition
snippet: Dave Keith scouted Gerrit Cole and Kyle Higashioka as amateurs in 2008 and immediately envisioned them as a battery in pinstripes. This year, it finally happened. SAN DIEGO — Dave Keith, a Yankees amateur scout, was on a road trip in Utah last month when he received a text message from Kyle Higashioka, the Yankees’ backup catcher. Higashioka wanted to know if Keith had received anything in the mail. Keith told him that he was on a scouting trip, but would give him a heads up when he got home.

headline: Jimmy Butler Finds the Best Spot to Revive the Heat: In the Paint
snippet: Grinding for layups, absorbing contact, drawing defenders and passing to teammates; Butler was Mr. Inside. LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Jimmy Butler scored and rebounded. He zipped no-look passes and threw himself into thickets of defenders. He barked at the most famous player in the world and hauled the Miami Heat back from the brink. The only thing Butler did not do on Sunday night was set up a pop-up stand at midcourt and sell more of his $20 cups of coffee.

headline: The Big Winner at the Transfer Window Was Jorge Mendes. Again.
snippet: The coronavirus pandemic has sent the soccer industry reeling, but money still flows to Mendes, one of the world’s most powerful agents. He just wrapped up another extremely profitable summer. The soccer economy is reeling. Every week there appears to be a new, dizzying figure highlighting the financial crunch the industry is facing as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. More than $115 million in losses at Barcelona alone. Hundreds of millions more in rebates to television rights holders. Across Europe, losses are expected to climb as high as $4.5 billion.

headline: Martina Trevisan’s French Open Is a Welcome Stop on the Long Path Back From Illness
snippet: Trevisan spent four years away from tennis as she was treated for an eating disorder. She recently opened up about her journey. PARIS — Martina Trevisan’s path to the French Open quarterfinals was harder to negotiate than the Arc de Triomphe roundabout. In a women’s draw that has seen most of the top-seeded players spin out, Trevisan personifies the resilience of those who have found a way through.

headline: Hope, Despair, Control: The 1950s China My Father Saw, Echoed Today

headline: The Work of David Gilkey, NPR Journalist Killed in Afghanistan
snippet: Mr. Gilkey, who was killed Sunday in Afghanistan along with his translator, Zabihullah Tamanna, was an award-winning photographer and videographer with wide experience around the globe.
